subject: Leadership
title: Stress and Performance
description: A micro-lesson that makes Stress and Performance usable.

hook.text: An athlete performs perfectly in practice but chokes at finals. Same skill, different pressure. Stress rewires brains.

buildup.text: The Yerkes-Dodson law: some stress helps performance, but too much destroys it. The curve is an inverted U.

discovery.text: Moderate stress sharpens focus and energy. Chronic stress shrinks the prefrontal cortex and impairs decision-making.

twist.text: Leaders mistake high-stress cultures for high-performance ones. Burnout isn't a badge of honor. It's a system failure.

climax.text: Find the sweet spot: enough challenge to engage, enough support to sustain. Monitor your team's stress, not just output.

punchline.text: Pressure creates diamonds, but too much crushes them.

quiz.question: What does the Yerkes-Dodson law describe?
options: More stress always equals better performance
An inverted-U relationship between stress and performance
Stress has no effect on performance
